title: Sets - Unique Collections
objectives: Understand what sets are and why uniqueness matters
Learn to create and modify sets
Master set operations: union, intersection, difference
Compare sets, lists, and dictionaries effectively

sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Sets: Collections of Unique Items

Real-World Analogy First:

Imagine a guest list for an exclusive event:

  • ğŸ« Each person can only be on the list ONCE (no duplicates)
  • ğŸ« Order doesn't matter (Alice being 1st or 5th doesn't change that she's invited)
  • ğŸ« You can quickly check: "Is Bob on the list?" (very fast lookup)
  • ğŸ« You can compare lists: "Who's invited to both events?" (intersection)
  • ğŸ« Or find: "Who's at Event A but NOT Event B?" (difference)

This is exactly what a Python set does - it's a collection where each item appears only once!

Now The Technical Term:

A set is an unordered collection of unique elements. No duplicates allowed, and no indexing (since there's no order).

Key Differences:

FeatureListSetDictionary
DuplicatesAllowedNot allowedKeys unique
OrderedYesNoInsertion order
IndexingYes [0]NoBy key
MutableYesYesYes
Syntax[]{}{k:v}

When to Use Sets:

  • âœ… Need to remove duplicates from data
  • âœ… Fast membership testing ("Is X in the collection?")
  • âœ… Mathematical set operations (union, intersection, difference)
  • âœ… Tracking unique items (unique visitors, tags, categories)
  • âŒ NOT when you need order or duplicates

sections.title: Code Example
sections.content:
ğŸ’» Working with Sets

Let's explore sets and their unique features:
sections.code:
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 1: Creating Sets
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 1: Creating sets")
print()

# Create with curly braces
fruits = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
print(f"Fruits set: {fruits}")
print(f"Type: {type(fruits)}")
print()

# Create from a list (automatically removes duplicates!)
numbers_with_dupes = [1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5]
unique_numbers = set(numbers_with_dupes)
print(f"List with duplicates: {numbers_with_dupes}")
print(f"Set (duplicates removed): {unique_numbers}")
print()

# Empty set (must use set(), not {})
empty_set = set()
empty_dict = {}  # This is a dict, not a set!
print(f"Empty set: {empty_set} (type: {type(empty_set)})")
print(f"Empty dict: {empty_dict} (type: {type(empty_dict)})")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 2: Sets Remove Duplicates
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 2: Automatic duplicate removal")
print()

# Duplicates are automatically removed
colors = {"red", "blue", "red", "green", "blue", "red"}
print(f"Set with duplicate attempts: {colors}")
print(f"Actual items in set: {len(colors)}")
print()

# Practical use: finding unique words
sentence = "the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog the fox"
words = sentence.split()
unique_words = set(words)
print(f"All words: {words}")
print(f"Unique words: {unique_words}")
print(f"Total: {len(words)}, Unique: {len(unique_words)}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 3: Set Operations - Add and Remove
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 3: Adding and removing items")
print()

tags = {"python", "programming", "tutorial"}
print(f"Original tags: {tags}")

# Add single item
tags.add("beginner")
print(f"After add('beginner'): {tags}")

# Add duplicate (no effect)
tags.add("python")
print(f"After add('python') again: {tags} (no change!)")

# Remove item
tags.remove("tutorial")
print(f"After remove('tutorial'): {tags}")

# Discard (won't error if item doesn't exist)
tags.discard("advanced")  # Not in set, but no error
print(f"After discard('advanced'): {tags} (no error)")

try:
    tags.remove("advanced")  # Would cause KeyError
except KeyError:
    print("remove('advanced') caused KeyError - item doesn't exist!")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 4: Set Operations - Union
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 4: Union - combine sets")
print()

set_a = {1, 2, 3, 4}
set_b = {3, 4, 5, 6}

print(f"Set A: {set_a}")
print(f"Set B: {set_b}")
print()

# Union: all items from both sets
union = set_a | set_b  # Using | operator
print(f"Union (A | B): {union}")

# Alternative syntax
union2 = set_a.union(set_b)
print(f"Union (A.union(B)): {union2}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 5: Set Operations - Intersection
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 5: Intersection - common items")
print()

# Intersection: items in BOTH sets
intersection = set_a & set_b  # Using & operator
print(f"Set A: {set_a}")
print(f"Set B: {set_b}")
print(f"Intersection (A & B): {intersection}")

# Alternative syntax
intersection2 = set_a.intersection(set_b)
print(f"Intersection (A.intersection(B)): {intersection2}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 6: Set Operations - Difference
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 6: Difference - items in one but not other")
print()

# Difference: in A but not in B
diff_a_b = set_a - set_b  # Using - operator
print(f"Set A: {set_a}")
print(f"Set B: {set_b}")
print(f"Difference (A - B): {diff_a_b}")
print(f"  (Items in A but NOT in B)")
print()

# Reverse: in B but not in A
diff_b_a = set_b - set_a
print(f"Difference (B - A): {diff_b_a}")
print(f"  (Items in B but NOT in A)")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 7: Practical Use - Finding Common Friends
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 7: Real-world example - Social network")
print()

alice_friends = {"Bob", "Carol", "Dave", "Eve"}
bob_friends = {"Alice", "Carol", "Frank", "George"}

print(f"Alice's friends: {alice_friends}")
print(f"Bob's friends: {bob_friends}")
print()

# Friends in common
common_friends = alice_friends & bob_friends
print(f"Friends in common: {common_friends}")

# Alice's friends that Bob doesn't know
alice_only = alice_friends - bob_friends
print(f"Alice's friends Bob doesn't know: {alice_only}")

# All friends (either Alice or Bob)
all_friends = alice_friends | bob_friends
print(f"All friends combined: {all_friends}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 8: Membership Testing (Very Fast!)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 8: Fast membership testing")
print()

allowed_users = {"alice", "bob", "carol", "dave"}

print(f"Allowed users: {allowed_users}")
print()

# Check if user is allowed (very fast operation)
users_to_check = ["alice", "eve", "bob", "frank"]
for user in users_to_check:
    if user in allowed_users:
        print(f"âœ… {user}: Access granted")
    else:
        print(f"âŒ {user}: Access denied")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 9: Removing Duplicates from List
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 9: Remove duplicates from a list")
print()

scores = [85, 92, 78, 92, 85, 88, 78, 95, 92]
print(f"Original scores: {scores}")
print(f"Count: {len(scores)}")

# Convert to set (removes duplicates), then back to list
unique_scores = list(set(scores))
print(f"\nUnique scores: {unique_scores}")
print(f"Count: {len(unique_scores)}")
print(f"Removed {len(scores) - len(unique_scores)} duplicates")

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Understanding Set Syntax and Operations

Part 1: Creating Sets

# Create with curly braces
my_set = {1, 2, 3}
         ^       ^  
         curly braces (like dict, but no colons)

# Create from list
my_set = set([1, 2, 3])
         ^^^  
         set() function

# Empty set (MUST use set(), not {})
empty = set()    # âœ… Correct - empty set
empty = {}       # âŒ Wrong - this is an empty DICT!

Part 2: Adding and Removing

# Add single item
my_set.add(item)  # Add one item

# Remove item (error if not exists)
my_set.remove(item)  # Raises KeyError if missing

# Discard item (no error)
my_set.discard(item)  # Silent if missing

# Clear all items
my_set.clear()  # Empty set

Part 3: Set Operations

OperationSymbolMethodMeaning
UnionA | BA.union(B)All items from both
IntersectionA & BA.intersection(B)Only common items
DifferenceA - BA.difference(B)In A but not B
Symmetric DiffA ^ BA.symmetric_difference(B)In either, not both

Visual Examples:

A = {1, 2, 3, 4}
B = {3, 4, 5, 6}

# Union (|): Everything
A | B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}
        â””â”€ All items from both sets

# Intersection (&): Overlap only
A & B = {3, 4}
        â””â”€ Only items in BOTH sets

# Difference (-): One-sided
A - B = {1, 2}
        â””â”€ In A but NOT in B

B - A = {5, 6}
        â””â”€ In B but NOT in A

# Symmetric Difference (^): Opposite of intersection
A ^ B = {1, 2, 5, 6}
        â””â”€ In either set, but NOT in both

Part 4: Membership Testing

if item in my_set:
    # Item exists

if item not in my_set:
    # Item doesn't exist
  • ğŸ“Œ Very fast operation (O(1) - constant time)
  • ğŸ“Œ Much faster than checking in a list

Part 5: Set vs List vs Dict

# LIST - ordered, allows duplicates
my_list = [1, 2, 2, 3]  # Keeps duplicates and order
first = my_list[0]      # Can index

# SET - unordered, no duplicates
my_set = {1, 2, 2, 3}   # Becomes {1, 2, 3}
first = my_set[0]       # âŒ Error! Can't index

# DICT - key-value pairs
my_dict = {"a": 1, "b": 2}  # Keys and values
value = my_dict["a"]        # Access by key

Part 6: Converting Between Types

# List â†’ Set (removes duplicates)
my_list = [1, 2, 2, 3]
my_set = set(my_list)  # {1, 2, 3}

# Set â†’ List (random order)
my_set = {1, 2, 3}
my_list = list(my_set)  # [1, 2, 3] or any order

# String â†’ Set (unique characters)
text = "hello"
chars = set(text)  # {'h', 'e', 'l', 'o'}

Part 7: Set Comprehensions (Preview)

# Create set with comprehension
squares = {x**2 for x in range(5)}
# Result: {0, 1, 4, 9, 16}

Important Limitations:

  • âŒ Can't index: my_set[0] causes error
  • âŒ Can't slice: my_set[1:3] causes error
  • âŒ Order not guaranteed: May appear in any order
  • âŒ Items must be immutable: Can't add lists or dicts to sets
# âœ… VALID set items
valid = {1, "text", 3.14, (1, 2), True}

# âŒ INVALID set items
invalid = {[1, 2]}  # Lists are mutable - TypeError!
invalid = {{"a": 1}}  # Dicts are mutable - TypeError!

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Student Course Analysis

Challenge: Use sets to analyze student enrollments across different courses.

Given Data:

cs101_students = {"Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Dave", "Eve"}
cs102_students = {"Bob", "Carol", "Frank", "Grace"}
math201_students = {"Alice", "Carol", "Dave", "Henry", "Iris"}

Requirements:

  1. Find students taking both CS101 and CS102 (intersection)
  2. Find students taking CS101 OR CS102 (union)
  3. Find students in CS101 but NOT in CS102 (difference)
  4. Find students taking all three courses
  5. Find students taking exactly one course (not in any other)
  6. Add a new student "Zara" to CS102
  7. Check if "Bob" is enrolled in Math201
  8. Create a set of all unique students across all courses
  9. Count how many students are taking at least 2 courses

Bonus: Find which students are taking only CS courses (not Math).
sections.starter_code:
# Given course enrollments
cs101_students = {"Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Dave", "Eve"}
cs102_students = {"Bob", "Carol", "Frank", "Grace"}
math201_students = {"Alice", "Carol", "Dave", "Henry", "Iris"}

print("ğŸ“š STUDENT COURSE ANALYSIS")
print("â•" * 60)
print(f"CS101 students: {cs101_students}")
print(f"CS102 students: {cs102_students}")
print(f"MATH201 students: {math201_students}")
print()

# Task 1: Students in both CS101 and CS102
print("Task 1: Students in both CS101 AND CS102")
# Your code here

# Task 2: Students in CS101 OR CS102
print("\nTask 2: Students in CS101 OR CS102")
# Your code here

# Task 3: Students in CS101 but NOT CS102
print("\nTask 3: Students in CS101 but NOT CS102")
# Your code here

# Task 4: Students in all three courses
print("\nTask 4: Students in ALL three courses")
# Your code here

# Task 5: Students in exactly one course
print("\nTask 5: Students in exactly ONE course")
# Your code here

# Task 6: Add Zara to CS102
print("\nTask 6: Adding Zara to CS102")
# Your code here

# Task 7: Check if Bob is in Math201
print("\nTask 7: Is Bob in Math201?")
# Your code here

# Task 8: All unique students
print("\nTask 8: All unique students")
# Your code here

# Task 9: Students taking at least 2 courses
print("\nTask 9: Students taking at least 2 courses")
# Your code here

# BONUS: Students taking only CS courses
print("\nBONUS: Students taking only CS courses (not Math)")
# Your code here

sections.title: Solution
sections.code:
# Given course enrollments
cs101_students = {"Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Dave", "Eve"}
cs102_students = {"Bob", "Carol", "Frank", "Grace"}
math201_students = {"Alice", "Carol", "Dave", "Henry", "Iris"}

print("ğŸ“š STUDENT COURSE ANALYSIS")
print("â•" * 60)
print(f"CS101 students ({len(cs101_students)}): {cs101_students}")
print(f"CS102 students ({len(cs102_students)}): {cs102_students}")
print(f"MATH201 students ({len(math201_students)}): {math201_students}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 1: Students in both CS101 and CS102 (INTERSECTION)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("Task 1: Students in BOTH CS101 AND CS102")
print("â”€" * 60)
both_cs = cs101_students & cs102_students  # Intersection
print(f"Students in both: {both_cs}")
print(f"Count: {len(both_cs)}")
for student in sorted(both_cs):
    print(f"  â€¢ {student}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 2: Students in CS101 OR CS102 (UNION)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 2: Students in CS101 OR CS102")
print("â”€" * 60)
any_cs = cs101_students | cs102_students  # Union
print(f"Students in either course: {any_cs}")
print(f"Count: {len(any_cs)}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 3: Students in CS101 but NOT CS102 (DIFFERENCE)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 3: Students in CS101 but NOT CS102")
print("â”€" * 60)
cs101_only = cs101_students - cs102_students  # Difference
print(f"CS101 only: {cs101_only}")
print(f"Count: {len(cs101_only)}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 4: Students in ALL three courses
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 4: Students in ALL three courses")
print("â”€" * 60)
all_three = cs101_students & cs102_students & math201_students
print(f"Students in all three: {all_three}")
if all_three:
    print(f"Count: {len(all_three)}")
    for student in sorted(all_three):
        print(f"  â€¢ {student}")
else:
    print("  (No students taking all three courses)")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 5: Students in exactly ONE course
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 5: Students in exactly ONE course")
print("â”€" * 60)

# Get all students
all_students = cs101_students | cs102_students | math201_students

# Check each student
exactly_one = set()
for student in all_students:
    courses_taking = 0
    if student in cs101_students:
        courses_taking += 1
    if student in cs102_students:
        courses_taking += 1
    if student in math201_students:
        courses_taking += 1
    
    if courses_taking == 1:
        exactly_one.add(student)

print(f"Students in exactly one course: {exactly_one}")
print(f"Count: {len(exactly_one)}")
for student in sorted(exactly_one):
    # Find which course
    if student in cs101_students:
        course = "CS101"
    elif student in cs102_students:
        course = "CS102"
    else:
        course = "MATH201"
    print(f"  â€¢ {student} ({course})")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 6: Add Zara to CS102
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 6: Adding Zara to CS102")
print("â”€" * 60)
print(f"Before: {cs102_students}")
cs102_students.add("Zara")
print(f"After: {cs102_students}")
print(f"âœ… Zara added to CS102 (now {len(cs102_students)} students)")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 7: Check if Bob is in Math201
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 7: Is Bob in Math201?")
print("â”€" * 60)
if "Bob" in math201_students:
    print("âœ… Bob is enrolled in Math201")
else:
    print("âŒ Bob is NOT enrolled in Math201")

# Check all Bob's courses
print("\nBob's enrollments:")
if "Bob" in cs101_students:
    print("  âœ… CS101")
if "Bob" in cs102_students:
    print("  âœ… CS102")
if "Bob" in math201_students:
    print("  âœ… MATH201")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 8: All unique students
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 8: All unique students across all courses")
print("â”€" * 60)
all_students = cs101_students | cs102_students | math201_students
print(f"All unique students: {all_students}")
print(f"Total: {len(all_students)} students")
print("\nAlphabetical list:")
for i, student in enumerate(sorted(all_students), 1):
    print(f"  {i}. {student}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 9: Students taking at least 2 courses
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 9: Students taking at least 2 courses")
print("â”€" * 60)

at_least_two = set()
for student in all_students:
    courses = []
    if student in cs101_students:
        courses.append("CS101")
    if student in cs102_students:
        courses.append("CS102")
    if student in math201_students:
        courses.append("MATH201")
    
    if len(courses) >= 2:
        at_least_two.add(student)
        print(f"  â€¢ {student}: {', '.join(courses)}")

print(f"\nCount: {len(at_least_two)} students taking at least 2 courses")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# BONUS: Students taking only CS courses (not Math)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nBONUS: Students taking only CS courses (not Math)")
print("â”€" * 60)

# Students in any CS course
cs_students = cs101_students | cs102_students

# Remove anyone in Math
cs_only = cs_students - math201_students

print(f"Students in CS but not Math: {cs_only}")
print(f"Count: {len(cs_only)}")
for student in sorted(cs_only):
    courses = []
    if student in cs101_students:
        courses.append("CS101")
    if student in cs102_students:
        courses.append("CS102")
    print(f"  â€¢ {student}: {', '.join(courses)}")

print("\n" + "â•" * 60)
print("Analysis complete!")
print("â•" * 60)

sections.explanation:
ğŸ“š Set Operations Explained:

  1. Intersection (&) - Items in Both (Line 18):
    both_cs = cs101_students & cs102_students
    • Returns only students in BOTH sets
    • Result: {"Bob", "Carol"}
    • Use when you need common elements
  2. Union (|) - Items in Either (Line 27):
    any_cs = cs101_students | cs102_students
    • Returns all students from BOTH sets
    • Automatically removes duplicates
    • Use when you need all unique items
  3. Difference (-) - Items in One, Not Other (Line 36):
    cs101_only = cs101_students - cs102_students
    • Students in CS101 but NOT in CS102
    • Order matters: A - B â‰  B - A
    • Use to find exclusive items
  4. Multiple Intersections (Line 44):
    all_three = cs101_students & cs102_students & math201_students
    • Chain intersections to find common across all
    • Only students in ALL three sets
  5. Membership Testing (Lines 59-70):
    for student in all_students:
    if student in cs101_students:
        courses_taking += 1
    • in operator is very fast for sets
    • Much faster than checking in lists
    • Perfect for filtering
  6. Adding to Set (Line 81):
    cs102_students.add("Zara")
    • Adds single item to set
    • If already exists, no change (no duplicates)
  7. Complex Set Logic (Line 122):
    cs_students = cs101_students | cs102_students
cs_only = cs_students - math201_students
    • Combine operations for complex queries
    • First: get all CS students (union)
    • Then: remove Math students (difference)

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips:

  • âœ… Use & for "both": Items in common
  • âœ… Use | for "either": All unique items
  • âœ… Use - for "not": Exclusion
  • âœ… Sets are fast: Membership testing is O(1)
  • âœ… Order doesn't matter: {1, 2, 3} == {3, 2, 1}

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Essential Points to Remember:

  1. Sets store unique items only:
    my_set = {1, 2, 2, 3}  # Becomes {1, 2, 3}
# No duplicates allowed!
  2. Sets are unordered:
    • No indexing: my_set[0] causes error
    • No slicing: my_set[1:3] causes error
    • Order may vary each time
  3. Create sets:
    my_set = {1, 2, 3}      # With curly braces
my_set = set([1, 2, 3]) # From list
empty = set()            # Empty set (NOT {}!)
  4. Four main set operations:
    OperationSymbolMeaning
    UnionA | BAll items from both
    IntersectionA & BOnly common items
    DifferenceA - BIn A but not B
    Symmetric DiffA ^ BIn either, not both
  5. Adding and removing:
    my_set.add(item)       # Add item
my_set.remove(item)    # Remove (error if missing)
my_set.discard(item)   # Remove (no error)
my_set.clear()         # Remove all
  6. Fast membership testing:
    if item in my_set:     # Very fast (O(1))
    # Item exists
  7. When to use sets:
    • âœ… Remove duplicates from data
    • âœ… Fast membership testing
    • âœ… Mathematical set operations
    • âœ… Tracking unique items
    • âŒ NOT when you need order
    • âŒ NOT when you need duplicates
  8. Set items must be immutable:
    # âœ… VALID
valid = {1, "text", (1, 2), 3.14}

# âŒ INVALID
invalid = {[1, 2]}      # Lists - mutable
invalid = {{"a": 1}}    # Dicts - mutable
  9. Converting types:
    # List with dupes â†’ Set (removes dupes)
my_set = set([1, 2, 2, 3])  # {1, 2, 3}

# Set â†’ List (random order)
my_list = list({1, 2, 3})   # [1, 2, 3]

# String â†’ Set (unique chars)
chars = set("hello")         # {'h', 'e', 'l', 'o'}
  10. Common patterns:
    # Remove duplicates
unique = list(set(my_list))

# Find common elements
common = set1 & set2

# Find differences
only_in_a = set1 - set2

# Combine unique items
all_items = set1 | set2

ğŸš€ Coming Up Next:

In the next lesson, you'll learn about Dictionary and Set Comprehensions - Pythonic one-liners for creating dictionaries and sets from existing data!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What makes a set different from a list?
options: Sets only store unique items and have no order
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Sets only store UNIQUE items (no duplicates) and have NO ORDER (can't index with [0]). Lists allow duplicates and maintain order. Both are mutable. Sets can store any immutable type, not just numbers. The uniqueness and unordered nature are the key differences.

checkpoint_quiz.question: What does set1 & set2 do?
options: Combines all items from both sets
Returns items that are in BOTH sets (intersection)
Returns items in set1 but not set2
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: The & operator returns the INTERSECTION - items that exist in BOTH sets. If set1 = {1, 2, 3} and set2 = {2, 3, 4}, then set1 & set2 = {2, 3}. Use | for union (all items), - for difference (one but not other).

checkpoint_quiz.question: How do you create an empty set?
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Use set() to create an empty set. {} creates an empty DICTIONARY, not a set! [] creates an empty list. set{} is invalid syntax. This is a common mistake - remember that {} without colons is ambiguous, so Python treats it as a dict.
